author: @sentdex
text: Apollo Clark Only a matter of time before someone has a bone to pick with what I said there. I don't want to turn this comment section into an argument about *what* php is, or *what* Wordpress is. There is no definitive, authoritative, answer, as these are just categories that we're imposing on things after-the-fact that aren't built to purposefully fit into categories for people.  Most people also put their foot down and say WordPress isn't a framework, and cite that it is a CMS. For whatever odd reason, people refuse to think of things as a spectrum, it must be "this" or "that."  Soon someone will probably come in here and argue with me about the "level" I called C as well.

author: @apolloclark
text: PHP is a programming language, not a framework. Laravel, Zend Framework, and Yii, are PHP frameworks. Wordpress is a Content Management System, which includes a framework. The biggest issues with large frameworks are architectural lock-in, and performance; ie, if I want a RESTful API, the framework needs to support it, or be flexible enough to add support to it, which Flask does very nicely.

I've read most of Miguel Grindberg's book on Flask, and think it's great. However there are some things he does I really don't get. I'm not even sure why he does some of the things he does in it, but for the most part it's a great book. Of course it's a Blog example, which I HATE! Anyways, curious if you've read it?
